videos.title: Selection Sort in Java BlueJ Explained | ICSE Computer Applications
videos.description:
Selection Sort divides the array into two parts sorted sub-array and unsorted sub-array. In each pass, it finds the minimum element of the unsorted sub-array and swaps it with the leftmost unsorted element moving the sorted sub-array one element to the right.

This lesson will explain us Selection Sort technique of sorting arrays. We will first understand Selection Sort through a real-world example and then go over the Selection Sort Java program in BlueJ to develop a thorough understanding of Selection Sort.

videos.title: Bubble Sort in Java BlueJ Explained | ICSE Computer Applications Class 10
videos.description:
Sorting means arranging the elements of the array in either ascending or descending order.  When things are sorted, it makes it easier for us to find them quickly. In Bubble Sort, we compare adjacent elements and swap them if they are in the wrong order.

This lesson explains Bubble Sort technique of sorting arrays. We will first understand Bubble Sort through a real-world example and then go over the Bubble Sort Java program in BlueJ to develop a thorough understanding of Bubble Sort.

videos.title: Binary Search in Arrays | Java & BlueJ | ICSE Computer Applications
videos.description:
The precondition to using Binary Search is that the array should be sorted. Binary Search is similar to how we search for a word in the dictionary. In Binary search, we divide the array successively into 2 halves and search for the element either in the first half or in the second half.

This lesson will explain us Binary Search technique of searching in arrays. We will first understand Binary Search through a real-world example and then go over the Binary Search Java program in BlueJ to develop a thorough understanding of Binary Search.

videos.title: Linear Search in Arrays | Java & BlueJ | ICSE Computer Applications
videos.description:
In linear search, we start at the beginning of the array and check to see if the first element is the element we are looking for. If it isnâ€™t we move to next element in the list and repeat the process until we have found our item or we reach the end of the array.

This lesson explains linear search technique of searching in arrays. We will first understand linear search through an example and then go over the linear search Java program in BlueJ to develop a thorough understanding of linear search.

videos.title: Single Dimensional Array: Creation with new Operator | Java & BlueJ | ICSE Computer Applications
videos.description:
Creating the array with new operator is a 2-step process. First declare the array - int arr[]. Then use the new operator to create the array - arr = new int[6]. This first statement just tells the compiler thatÂ we intend to use arr as an int array. It doesnâ€™t create any array. The second statement actuallyÂ creates the array.

In this lesson, we will learn about creating an array using the new operator. We will also learn about default values of arrays of different data types and how we can assign values to individual elements of the array.

videos.title: Introduction to Objects & Classes | ICSE Computer Applications | Java & BlueJ
videos.description:
Classes and Objects are at the heart of Object-Oriented Programming. Object is an entity having a specific identity, specific characteristics and specific behavior. A Class is a blueprint that represents a set of objects that share common characteristics and behaviour.

This lesson explains the concept of Objects and Classes in Object-Oriented programming by going through several real-world examples. By the end of this lesson you will be able to identify the objects around you and categorize them in classes.

videos.title: Code Blocks & Tokens | ICSE Computer Applications | Java & BlueJ
videos.description:
Code blocks and tokens are fundamental units of all Java programs. A group of statements enclosed within curly braces is called a Code Block. A token is the smallest element of a program that is meaningful to the compiler.

This video explains the fundamental units of all Java programs - Code Blocks and Tokens. It shows how if and for statements use code blocks and introduces all the different tokens in Java.

videos.description:
In this video, we will learn about finite and infinite loops in Java. We will walkthrough a fewÂ example BlueJ programs which will show us the practical applications of infinite loops.

A loop which iterates for a finite number of iterations is termed as a Finite loop. A loop which continues iterating indefinitely and never stops is termed as an infinite loop. A loop becomes an infinite loop when its condition always evaluates to true.
